Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Coastal Research in Environmental Science and Technology (CREST) at UMass Boston
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides new funding for a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at the University of Massachusetts Boston (UMass Boston). The Coastal Research in Environmental Science and Technology (CREST) REU site and is a 10-week research/educational program designed to expose 10 undergraduates per year to cutting edge, integrative, coastal environmental science research. Mentors will be available from the Environmental, Earth and Ocean Sciences department and the Biology department at UMass Boston. Each CREST scholar will work with a research mentor to develop/conduct a research project in an area of coastal environmental science or technology appropriate to each scholar's background and interests. Students will gain hands-on experience with cutting-edge instrumentation, field experiences, and training in coastal marine data collection and will participate in professional development activities that will develop skills in data interpretation and scientific writing, teamwork and leadership skills, and scientific ethics. The primary broader impacts of CREST are the recruitment and training of future researchers and educators in the coastal environmental sciences. The primary undergraduate population targeted by the program includes not only rising juniors but also younger students with strong interest in interdisciplinary research and coastal environmental science. NSF funding provides for student stipends, housing in univerisity apartments, student laboraotry and field trip expenses, and some administrative costs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Coastal Research in Environmental Science and Technology (CREST) Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) program in the School for the Environment at the University of Massachusetts Boston was first funded by the National Science Foundation in 2011.  The objectives of our project were 1) to select a diverse cohort of participants (students and mentors), 2) to provide professional development and training, 3) to provide an excellent research experience, and 4) to develop on of the students first peer and mentor networks. The CREST REU selected a diverse [discipline, grade level, university type, underrepresented minorities (ethnic, disabled, and veterans)] cohort of 10 students per year (plus 2 on a supplement) based on our web based application system.  Participants conducted scholarship/research with mentors, were provided professional development activities of scientific communication, responsible conduct in research, and hot topic seminars/discussion periods, and were immersed in social activities for cohort development and networking.  From 2011-2013, the CREST REU had a 100% completion rate for the 10-week summer program.  Participants have made presentations at national and international meetings and are publishing their results in peer-reviewed journals.  Twenty-seven of the 32 participants have graduated in their major with the remainder on track to graduate in 2016. Furthermore, of the graduated students 28% have Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) related jobs, 20% have non-STEM related jobs, 36% are in STEM graduate school, and 16% are in non-STEM graduate school.  Of the three non-graduated students, all three report that they are applying to STEM graduate school.  Both post program and long term evaluations indicate that the CREST REU program is effective in achieving its goals and objectives.
